Award.AbstractNarration: The usefulness of any model experimental system depends on the extent to which it is able to mimic normal in vivo responses. A case in point is models that use controlled tissue culture environments to investigate how neurons grow. Most researchers fail to account for all key influences that neurons encounter in the embryo, particularly the mechanical behavior of embryonic tissue. This omission turns out to be critical. Evidence from the P.I.'s laboratory shows that unless the tissue culture environment mimics the mechanical status of the embryo, certain neurons are unable to respond normally to critical guidance cues. Very little is known about how mechanical signals impact neuronal responses to molecular guidance cues. These experiments address that deficit using a tissue culture model developed by the P.I. to account for the mechanical status of the embryo. They focus on a protein that plays a key regulatory role in how neurons respond to both mechanical and molecular signals. With the aim of unraveling mechanisms that coordinate neuronal responses to molecular guidance cues in the embryo, these investigators will use biochemical and molecular approaches to manipulate the mechanical environment. Their ultimate goal is to construct a tissue culture model with maximum in vivo relevance to both neurons and other mechanosensitive cells. The work has broader impact by virtue of two K-12 outreach programs established by the P.I. The first has sponsored over 200 inner city students to perform inquiry-based projects in research laboratories. The second has established professional development for their teachers. This award will expand opportunities for both students and their teachers to participate in authentic inquiry-based research, reinforcing the STEM educational pipeline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are particularly interested in how the connections between functional units of the brain are initially established, especially in the cortex. The cortex is the region in the brain that receives all our sensory input and then converts it into intention to act and hence into actions. It also integrates other information so that the action is appropriate.

Obviously we can’t use human neurons, so we turn to mouse models which function pretty much like humans.  One classic way to work with mouse neurons is to separate the individual neurons from a living brain then grow them a dish. Thousands of studies are published using this simple model every year.

When we first started this study, we were puzzled that neurons in this model didn't behave how we expected. We knew that in a whole brain  molecules act as guideposts to set up functional connections. The guidepost molecule we are interested in is called ‘netrin’ because it is important in the developing cortex. We wanted to know how netrins control  growing neurons. Neurons growing in a plastic dish didn’t respond as if they were in the whole animal. Their growth slowed down and they behaved like they had already reached their target, not as if they were on their way to it, making decisions about where to connect. We were very confused.

We started thinking about the plastic dish we were growing the neurons in. We had tried to provide the neurons with an environment as much like the brain as possible in terms of the nutrients they need – indeed they survived quite happily. But it dawned on us that we hadn’t mimicked one key aspect of the brain – how soft it is! A plastic dish is obviously very hard but the brain, especially in the mouse embryo where most growth takes place is very soft. This study asked the question – if we want to investigate how neurons work, how important is it to mimic the softness of the brain when we grow neurons in a dish? Obviously, if it is very important, then those thousands of studies that didn’t take this factor into consideration could be problematic.

The first thing we did was to figure out how soft embryonic cortex is using a technique called ‘atomic force microscopy’ that probes the embryonic brain. Then we figured out how to make a gel that was as soft as the brain, stick it to the plastic dish and coat it with the sticky surface that neurons like to grow on. Then  we could ask how it affected the neurons ability to grow in response to the guidepost molecule netrin we were interested in.

The results were even more surprising than we expected. First, we found that when we gave neurons growing on the soft gel netrin it didn’t immediately cause them to grow. It first switched on the stem cells so that they made neurons. This was unexpected.  Next how netrin affected the electrical response of the neuron changed, finally how the neurons organized themselves in order to be able to respond to the netrin also changed. This last effect is particularly important because when netrin signals to a neuron the signaling mechanisms that respond can have other effects inside the neuron.  By showing that the softness of the gel effects how a neuron responds to netrin confirms that many of the often elaborate studies done growing neurons on hard plastic dishes are problematic. However another wrinkle is that not all neurons seem to be as sensitive to softness as cortex neurons.  We also investigated how cortex neurons and spinal cord neurons respond to netrin in the whole animal. We found that spinal neurons are less sensitive to softness than cortex neurons. Many of the studies investigating how netrin works used spinal neurons, which may explain why, even on hard surfaces like plastic, cortex and spinal neurons respond differently to netrin.
